According to several reports, Kylian Mbappe will join Real Madrid and the he will be officially announced by the club within this week. From winning the 15th UCL to signing one of the best players in the world, the week has been a win-win for the Spanish club.\n\nAlso Read:Madrid plot 16th CL triumph; Mbappe would further bolster the squad\n\nJose Mourinho made a huge statement on the effect of Kylian Mbappe on Jude Bellingham\n\nJude Bellingham's goal total may drop next season, according to Jose Mourinho, since Kylian Mbappe is joining Real Madrid. He expects that Bellingham's location farther from the goal will affect his chances of scoring. Following Real Madrid's 2-0 Champions League final victory over Borussia Dortmund, Mourinho said in a TNT Sports interview that Carlo Ancelotti is probably going to favour an offensive three of Mbappe, Vinicius Jr., and Rodrygo. As such, Bellingham would be moved to play in the midfield with Federico Valverde, Eduardo Camavinga, and Aurelien Tchouamen. (via Metro) He added:\n\n\"Bellingham will score less goals next season. Because the system is going to change, the position of Bellingham is going to change. They will play Rodrygo, Mbappe and Vinicius Jr, they will play three. For me, he [Carlo Ancelotti] will play with two midfield players and Bellingham behind the three attacking players. So in midfield he will play probably [Federico] Valverde, [Eduardo] Camavinga and [Aurelien] Tchouameni, and Luka [Modric] coming when the game needs eyes. {"uri": "8159173902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "10:55:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T10:55:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T10:54:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/real-madrid-dominate-decade-kylian-105006406.html", "title": "Real Madrid should dominate for a decade with Kylian Mbappe and a new role for Jude Bellingham", "body": "As Borussia Dortmund became the latest team to discover, facing Real Madrid in a European final almost always ends the same way.\n\nThere was an inevitability about Madrid's record-extending 15th European crown at Wembley on Saturday, as they won 2-0 after being outplayed for 70 minutes.\n\nMadrid have won the Champions League six times in the past 11 years and last lost a European final in 1983.\n\nGetting the job done when it matters most is what they do, and their stronghold over the continent is set to tighten further this week when they announce the signing of Kylian Mbappe from Paris Saint-Germain on a free transfer.\n\nMbappe has been the natural heir to Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo as the superstar of world football, and the prospect of him linking up with Jude Bellingham and Vinicius Jr will scare the rest of Europe.\n\nThe France captain is the most devastating forward in the world. His 364 goal contributions in 308 matches for PSG will now be added to a front three featuring Vinicius and Rodrygo.\n\nBellingham is set for a deeper role at Madrid next season, with Brazilian prodigy Endrick also joining in a \u00a351million deal from Palmeiras.\n\nThose five players have an average age under 22 and Madrid could, perhaps should, dominate European football for the next decade. Their combined potential is frightening.\n\nMbappe will immediately become the jewel in their star line-up. The feeling is that he will have to play as an out-and-out No9 -- a role he has not particularly liked with PSG or France. Mbappe prefers to play from the left flank, but Vinicius is set to be retained there, with Rodrygo on the right.\n\nBellingham will drop into a midfield three alongside Federico Valverde and either Aurelien Tchouameni or Eduardo Camavinga.\n\n\"Bellingham will score fewer goals next season,\" former Madrid manager Jose Mourinho said while working as a pundit for TNT Sports on Saturday. \"The system is going to change, the position of Bellingham is going to change.\"\n\nMbappe's arrival will bring a different dynamic to the squad, but if any coach can make it work, then it is Carlo Ancelotti.\n\nThe Italian has now won the Champions League five times as a manager and yesterday recreated his cigar celebration with the Madrid players during their celebrations in the Spanish capital.\n\nMadrid will be favourites to retain the Champions League next season, and Bellingham is excited about the prospect of working with Mbappe.\n\nSpeaking after the game on Saturday, he said: \"Tonight, the only little thing we were missing was that clinical No9. And if he [Mbappe] was to come and give us that, we'd be in a really great place. {"uri": "8159815399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "18:06:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T18:06:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T18:05:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.football.london/arsenal-fc/transfer-news/arsenal-handed-ultimate-kylian-mbappe-29287917", "title": "Real Madrid end Arsenal Kylian Mbappe transfer hope with final confirmation", "body": "Real Madrid have confirmed the signing of Kylian Mbappe from Paris Saint-Germain. It ends years of speculation an drama around the Frenchman.\n\nMbappe will join the 15-time Champions League winners on a free transfer from PSG after failing to agree another new contract with the Ligue 1 giants. It also puts to bed any outside opportunity for Premier League clubs to sign the 25-year-old.\n\nArsenal had been linked with the World Cup golden boot winner after Mikel Arteta opened up how the club should deal with his availability. Speaking in January he said, \"\"Why not?\" when asked if the Gunners should be in for signing Mbappe.\"If we want to be the best team, we are going to need the best talent and the best players, that is for sure.\"\n\nAs for Chelsea, they had Mbappe on trial as a teenager but failed to get a deal over the line. He instead opted to move to Monaco, where he built up his standing as superstar in the making.\n\nMbappe then made the big-money switch to PSG via a loan. He went on to become the club's all-time top scorer before eventually being snapped up by Madrid following two years of public flirting with the idea as well as broken promises.\n\nHe will leave PSG with more goals than any other player though after a staggering 256 in 308 games for the club. He also managed 108 assists, though wasn't able to deliver the holy grail in Europe.\n\nREAD MORE: Arsenal news and transfers: LIVE!\n\nREAD MORE: Man United set to complete second Arsenal raid as Mikel Arteta prepared to lose key figure\n\nMbappe has already played two World Cup finals, winning one, as well as lifting the French domestic league title seven times. He now joins Madrid just days after Carlo Ancelotti led them to a sixth Champions League success in the past 11 years.\n\nIt is a transfer that makes them even more powerful than they already were. For Arsenal it is a case of what-if after Arsene Wenger admitting making serious moves to get him to north London.\n\n\"You know at one point I tried to convince him to come to Arsenal,\" he said in a BBC documentary about the global icon. \"I was at his home with his parents. He was a happy boy. He just wanted to play football and had the passion for the game.\"\n\nFormer scout Giles Grimandi said similar. \"We met his parents in London who came to the training ground and alongside Arsene and Richard Law [then transfer chief] we travelled to meet Kylian in the South of France.\n\n\"We tried, and I really don't think we were far from getting him, but he declined the project and signed a new deal with Monaco. {"uri": "8158056493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-02", "time": "16:18:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-02T16:18:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-02T16:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/rodrygo-responds-to-real-madrid-exit-rumours-amid-liverpool-and-man-city-interest/", "title": "Rodrygo responds to Real Madrid exit rumours amid Liverpool and Man City interest", "body": "Rodrygo secured his second UEFA Champions League winners medal with Real Madrid on Saturday\n\nHighlights Rodrygo has responded to rumours linking him with a move away from Real Madrid Liverpool and Manchester City are among the clubs linked with the Brazil international The player won his second UEFA Champions League trophy with Los Blancos on Saturday night\n\nRodrygo has made his stance on a possible exit from Real Madrid abundantly clear following their UEFA Champions League triumph over Dortmund at Wembley on Saturday night, amid interest from Manchester City and Liverpool.\n\nGoals from Dani Carvajal and Vinicius Junior in the second-half set Los Blancos on their way to an unprecedented 15th Champions League title. No European club is close to matching that feat, with AC Milan the next most decorated team in the competition with seven honours, closely followed by Liverpool and Bayern Munich on six.\n\nRodrygo, described as 'special' by Ancelotti, has been at Real Madrid since 2019 following a move from Brazilian outfit Santos. Throughout his five years in Spain so far, he has scored 54 goals and registered 41 assists in over 200 appearances across all competitions.\n\nRodrygo responds to exit rumours Liverpool and Man City have been linked\n\nThe 23-year-old's future has been at the centre of speculation in recent months due to the highly anticipated arrivals of Kylian Mbappe, as well as Rodrygo's compatriot and 17-year-old wonderkid, Endrick.\n\nLiverpool have been linked with Rodrygo for quite some time, while Spanish outlet MARCA recently tipped Manchester City as a potential destination for the player, should he depart the Bernabeu. However, it seems it is the Brazilian's desire to move absolutely nowhere as he basks in yet more success with Real Madrid.\n\nJournalist Fabrizio Romano recently reported Rodrygo intends to stay put in Spain and honour the contract extension he signed only last November. On Saturday, in the aftermath of the team's victory in London, he addressed the rumours once more.\n\nRodrygo told reporters:\n\n\"This week some media said about bids, clubs, interest... I don't know anything about it and I'm not interested. Even if there are proposals, I have no idea about that... I'm staying. I'm happy here. How can I leave Real Madrid?\"\n\nMbappe to complete Real Madrid move Rodrygo might struggle for game time amid Liverpool and City links\n\nIn what has been Europe's worst kept secret, Kylian Mbappe has, according to reports, finally completed his move from Paris Saint-Germain to Real Madrid. The France international has long been primed for a move to the Bernabeu and it is now, at long last, about to happen.\n\nMbappe is out of contract at PSG this summer and will complete a free transfer to Real Madrid. {"uri": "8159828502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "18:18:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T18:18:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T18:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/sport/international/a/2201496.html", "title": "Mbappe fulfils destiny with Real Madrid move", "body": "The first time Real Madrid showed an interest in signing Kylian Mbappe was in December 2012 -- although he was only approaching his 14th birthday the Spanish giants knew they were looking at a prodigious talent.\n\nMbappe, who was living at the French Football Federation's academy at Clairefontaine at the time, was invited to Madrid for a week, taken to a game at the Santiago Bernabeu and to the club's training ground where he met Zinedine Zidane and Cristiano Ronaldo.\n\nThe young Kylian idolised Ronaldo, decorating his bedroom with posters of the Portuguese superstar. There is a famous picture of Ronaldo with his arm around the youngster, who only comes up to his hero's shoulder.\n\nOn Monday, he posted on X that the move was \"a dream come true\", yet it has taken more than a decade for Mbappe to make it back to Madrid to play for the 15-time European champions.\n\nMadrid tried again to sign Mbappe in the summer of 2017, but Paris Saint-Germain lured him away from Monaco.\n\nReal made a further attempt to buy him in 2021 and to sign him in 2022, before he agreed to extend his stay at PSG. Now, however, Real have their man.\n\nHe leaves PSG at the age of 25, after seven prolific years in which he became his hometown club's all-time top scorer but never managed to win the Champions League.\n\nIt has been a slow goodbye to Paris, but things have usually moved fast for Mbappe in his career, almost as fast as the player himself in full flight.\n\nThere are few more thrilling sights in modern football than Mbappe racing at an opposition defence. His pace is astonishing. He is a voracious goal-scorer and is still a player who can dominate the sport for years to come.\n\nEven though PSG had already started the process of building for a future without Mbappe, his departure is a monumental blow for the club.\n\n- Bondy boy -\n\nIt is significant move too for Mbappe, the boy brought up in Bondy, the commune in the deprived Seine-Saint-Denis department which makes up the inner north-eastern suburbs of Paris.\n\nBondy is immensely proud of Kylian, whose father Wilfried coached him at the local club and whose mother, Fayza, was a handball player.\n\nAfter Mbappe signed for PSG a mural appeared on the side of an apartment block overlooking the canal that runs from central Paris up through Bondy. It was accompanied by the slogan: \"Bondy, Ville des Possibles\" -- the town where anything is possible.\n\nMbappe's upbringing was unlike most in Bondy. He went to a private school, for example. But he is an icon there, and throughout France.\n\nYet he always wanted to go to Madrid one day, just as they were desperate to sign him.\n\n\"Real wanted Kylian but we wouldn't really have had our bearings there had we gone,\" recalled Mbappe's father, who helped his son, and many other budding players, develop as a youth coach in Bondy.\n\nInstead, the youngster joined Monaco in 2013, Wilfried moving down to the Mediterranean with him.\n\n- Ballon d'Or one day? -\n\nHis arrival in the principality did not go unnoticed, with Le Parisien dedicating an article \"to one of the great hopes of his generation\", who was photographed holding a Monaco shirt with the number seven on the back.\n\nMbappe, it said, had already signed a deal with Nike. He revealed his plan to the newspaper, \"to one day win the Ballon d'Or\".\n\nHe was still 16 when he made his first-team debut for Monaco in December 2015, beating Thierry Henry's record to become the principality side's youngest ever player.\n\nSoon he became their youngest ever goal-scorer, and in the following 2016/17 season he starred in a Monaco team that reached the Champions League semi-finals and netted 15 times as they won the Ligue 1 title.\n\nA sensational 180 million-euro transfer to PSG followed at the age of 18.\n\nThe next year he won the World Cup, becoming the first teenager since Pele in 1958 to score in the final, as France beat Croatia 4-2 in Moscow.\n\nThere was also his stunning hat-trick in the 2022 World Cup final, which France lost on penalties to Lionel Messi's Argentina.\n\nHe has just finished as Ligue 1's leading scorer for a sixth straight season. He has won the French title seven times, but now he will hope a move to Madrid can finally see him win the Champions League and the Ballon d'Or.\n\nBefore that he will be aiming to lead his country to glory at the European Championship in Germany.", "source": {"uri": "today.rtl.lu", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTL Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8159064367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "09:47:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T09:47:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T09:46:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5289747/2024/06/03/fm24-real-madrid-kylian-mbappe/", "title": "Simulating Mbappe's Real Madrid career in Football Manager 24", "body": "\"The more difficult the victory, the greater the happiness in winning.\"\n\nThis quote is attributed to football legend Pele, who proclaimed that tougher obstacles produce greater feelings of joy. With Kylian Mbappe joining an already-stacked Real Madrid side, it may be time to rethink that saying.\n\nBut will Real's new-look team be as good as advertised on paper and win an abundance of trophies with ease now they've recruited one of the world's best forwards? There is only one way to find out: by loading up Football Manager 2024 and running a bunch of experiments in the interest of producing serious, accurate and reliable journalism.\n\nWe simulated Mbappe's entire career at Real Madrid, which lasted 11 seasons, in FM24 to see how things might play out. Here are the results.\n\nA domestic double looks nice on paper and ticks a bunch of boxes, but considering the strength of Real Madrid's new-look side, there is an unwritten expectation that this team should be winning the treble more seasons than not.\n\nReal Madrid won the league by 17 points, but they did not blow away their opposition in Europe, losing to RB Leipzig in the round of 16 in the Champions League.\n\nIt was a fun start to a new Galactico era. Mbappe played up front, rather than on the left, and he won trophies, but an early exit in Europe had doubters lining up by the droves to criticise his decision to leave Paris.\n\nFor Mbappe, it is heartbreaking. For the neutral, it is probably the outcome they wanted most in the interest of keeping a healthy competitive balance. With a domestic double once again secured, this time round, Real made the Champions League final and came up against their biggest rivals, Barcelona -- and lost 2-0.\n\nThey also lost the Club World Cup final to Manchester City, so they could not even call themselves \"world champions\". Once again, they were close, but no cigar.\n\nVinicius Junior and Rodrygo both scored more league goals than Mbappe, whose total of 25 across all competitions was one less than the aforementioned duo.\n\nReal's transfer outlay was modest, with only \u00a320million spent on Kalidou Koulibaly (\u00a315million), Renato Sanches (\u00a32.5million) and Angelino (\u00a32.5million). Given the depth of their squad, oddly enough, not many people were quick to offer sympathy towards their lack of spending.\n\nWith Carlo Ancelotti still in charge, the expectations placed upon the Italian manager were rising in Spain's capital. Mbappe alternated between playing up front and also as a left-winger, but his team regressed.\n\nFor the past two years, they won the league, Copa del Rey and Spanish Super Cup. In season three, they \"only\" won La Liga, albeit by 13 points. It is fair to wonder if they could have achieved the same results without Mbappe.\n\nSome of their transfer moves were questionable, too. Real spent \u00a345million on Arnaut Danjuma, but he only made one start in the league all season. Leon Goretzka, who at this point is 31 years old, started plenty of games but did not post an average rating above 7/10, which is considered the benchmark for a good performance in FM24.\n\nThree seasons in, Real Madrid are undoubtedly a domestic force, winning three La Liga titles in a row for the first time since Barcelona achieved the feat between 2008 and 2011. But in Europe, it was an Erling Haaland-led Manchester City side who reigned supreme, with Pep Guardiola's side making it two Champions League wins in three seasons.\n\nAnother year, another easy title victory. Real have clearly proven to be the best team in Spain so far during this experiment. They finished 14 points ahead of Barcelona in second place, which follows on from previous point differentials of 17, 13 and 13 respectively.\n\nGiven they have established themselves as the dominant force in Spain, we will give them some leeway for yet another campaign with no Champions League triumph. Would they care for my leeway in real life? I am guessing not, but I am going to excuse their continental failures regardless.\n\nMbappe had another decent season. He once again outperformed his xG by around 10 goals and provided a modest return of 15 league goals.\n\nTheir only notable additions to their starting line-up are Borussia Dortmund full-back Julian Ryerson and Chelsea's Benoit Badiashile. For what it is worth, Ancelotti is still the manager. Is he the reason they have not yet won another European trophy since signing Mbappe? Only time will tell.\n\nThe wheels are starting to fall off. For the first time in five seasons, Real Madrid did not win a single trophy.\n\nAnother mediocre display in the Champions League, coupled with Barcelona finally ending their domestic dominance, left the club in a tricky position.\n\nMbappe did, however, reach a personal milestone. He finished joint-top scorer in La Liga alongside former Coventry striker Viktor Gyokeres, but that is a small consolation in an otherwise disappointing season.\n\nThe club's transfer strategy left a lot to be desired, too. The headline additions were Crystal Palace's Tyrick Mitchell and Joe Gomez, who at this point played for PSG but moved to Spain's capital and did not feature much.\n\nSix seasons into this experiment and still no Champions League victory in sight. Real exited the tournament at the quarter-final stage against Bayern Munich. They won the Club World Cup, which put a band-aid over an increasingly large and gaping continental-sized wound.\n\nIf Mbappe went six seasons without any success in Europe, people would have plenty of questions. They did win the league again, so it was not all bad.\n\nMbappe chipped in with 30 goal contributions in all competitions, but his team's inability to get over the final hurdle in Europe meant a lot of those goals he scored in the early rounds of the Copa del Rey were far less significant.\n\nContinuing with their theme of signing random Premier League players, Real signed Ibrahima Konate for \u00a358million alongside two regenerated players, bringing their total outlay for the season to \u00a3119million. Mbappe is now 30, entering the final year of his deal and Ancelotti has retired. The clock is ticking.\n\nThe stage was set for one of the most Hollywood-style endings to a season in recent memory. Jurgen Klopp took charge of Real Madrid and their final fixture of the season was the Champions League final. Their opponents? Liverpool.\n\nIf they won, it would complete a historic treble, having already won the league and Copa del Rey. So what did they do? They lost 3-1.\n\nA return of 19 goals in all competitions seems a little low, but Mbappe did miss a chunk of time with injury, including the Champions League. Outside of that, Real's domestic dominance continued, so it was not all bad.\n\nThey spent \u00a3191million on new players, with \u00a395million of that going on French goalkeeper Guillaume Restes, with the other \u00a396million spent on made-up, regenerated players. Mbappe extended his deal by an extra year, but there was a lot of uncertainty heading into year eight.\n\nNot to be deterred by a painful defeat against Liverpool, Real once again made it to the Champions League and faced Manchester City, who were managed by Unai Emery at this point in the experiment. They won the league by 20 points, which was their seventh title in the last eight seasons and also won the Copa del Rey.\n\nThe treble was right there for the taking -- and they took it, beating City 2-1, with Mbappe missing a penalty that ultimately did not prove too costly.\n\nIt took them eight years but they finally did it. Mbappe did not exactly cover himself in glory during Real's European exploits -- he only scored twice and missed a penalty in the final. In La Liga, he was the second-highest scorer. He alternated between playing on the left and up front and produced solid numbers: 27 goals and 16 assists for the season.\n\nHe has not yet won the Ballon d'Or but did extend his contract by another year, so there is still time.\n\nIt was worth the wait. After going seven seasons without a Champions League title, Real now had two in two years, but Mbappe, who was now in the \"father time\" period of his career at 33 years old, did not play a large role in winning the double.\n\nHe missed three months of the season with injury and also was not fit for the final against Manchester City. He once again extended his contract, but his importance was declining, with regenerated player Daniel Kuche now the star of the team.\n\nYet Real's central midfield trio of Bellingham, Camavinga and Tchouameni aged like a fine wine. That base in the centre of the park is the bedrock of this trophy-laden run, with Vinicius Jr, Rodrygo and Mbappe doing their bit, too.\n\nFor anyone wondering how Endrick, one of the best wonderkids in FM23, was getting on, the Brazilian had only scored 32 league goals in eight seasons in Madrid.\n\nThere was to be no three-peat as Real were knocked out of the Champions League by Manchester City in the semi-finals in Mbappe's 10th season at the club. They won the league once again, as well as the Club World Cup and Copa del Rey.\n\nMbappe had interest from clubs in Saudi Arabia but ultimately chose to extend his deal by another year -- therefore extending my time monitoring this simulation. I was hoping he would accept that big payday from Al Ittihad, but instead, I had to make my sixth iced coffee of the day and soldier on.\n\nVinicius Jr won the Ballon d'Or for the second year in a row and 34-year-old Trent Alexander-Arnold has just signed for Real on a free transfer.\n\nDespite having another year left on his contract, Mbappe decided to hang up his boots in July 2034.\n\nReal Madrid coasted to yet another league title but Mbappe played a very small part in that. He only started nine games in the league and was largely an afterthought as Real won La Liga.\n\nHis final year in Madrid was understandably quiet, given he was now 35 years old and way past his prime.\n\nMbappe was an important piece in the jigsaw, but history will remember Vinicius Jr as the unquestioned leader of Real Madrid's dominant run across these 11 seasons.\n\nThe Brazilian won the Ballon d'Or twice and Bellingham won it once. Mbappe managed a third-placed finish in 2031, but if two of your team-mates were crowned as the world's best player, it is hard to argue that you were the driving force of that dynasty.\n\nBut he was still important. Mbappe, who was used as a centre-forward more often than he was a left-winger, played a significant role in helping Real Madrid to render the competitiveness of La Liga to that of Ligue 1, where one team (PSG) reigns supreme every year.\n\nIn total, Mbappe won 25 trophies in Madrid and won 10 out of 11 league titles on offer. They won the league by an average margin of 13.6 points during that time, too.\n\nA return of only two Champions League titles could be improved upon, with both of those victories happening after Mbappe had turned 30, but his team's domestic performance was so strong that even his fiercest critics may overlook that. His individual numbers were impressive, too.\n\nMbappe was never the league's top scorer, but a return of 34 goal contributions per season on average is a healthy return and undoubtedly helped Real Madrid become historically dominant in La Liga but less so in Europe.\n\nManchester City, led by Erling Haaland, managed four Champions League victories and eight Premier League titles during this experiment. They were the most dominant team in the entire world.\n\nReal Madrid spent years trying to sign Mbappe. They finally got him and he ended his career in this painstaking 11-season FM24 simulation with two Champions League titles but no Ballon d'Or win. Was it worth it? "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/sport/international/a/2201491.html", "title": "'A thrilling link-up': Mbappe, Vinicius, Bellingham to form Madrid's dream attacking trio", "body": "Kylian Mbappe has finally signed for Real Madrid but fans must wait a few more weeks before a thrilling link-up with Vinicius Junior and Jude Bellingham becomes a reality.\n\nThe French forward will lead one of the most potent forward lines in world football after he arrives from Paris Saint-Germain at the end of his contract, a heady blend of skill, speed and dynamism.\n\nA lethal trio of such unequivocal quality brings to mind the new European and Spanish champions' glittering era with Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale and Karim Benzema causing havoc.\n\nThat vaunted 'BBC' trident inspired Madrid to multiple Champions League triumphs over the past decade, including three in a row between 2016 and 2018.\n\nMbappe idolised Ronaldo as a child and now has the chance to emulate the Portuguese forward, Madrid's all-time top goalscorer, in the Spanish capital.\n\nIn 2017 Mbappe turned down a potential move to Madrid from Monaco, in part because of the strength of the trio of attackers who seemed impossible to dislodge.\n\nNow Mbappe, who played alongside ageing former Barcelona attackers Lionel Messi and Neymar in Paris, will be the elder statesman at only 25.\n\nWorryingly for the rest of Europe, the trio are only improving, with Bellingham and Vinicius 20 and 23 years old respectively, leading Madrid to La Liga and Champions League glory this season.\n\nMbappe and Vinicius could lead the line with Bellingham supporting in an attacking midfield role.\n\nMadrid coach Carlo Ancelotti unlocked Bellingham's goalscoring prowess by deploying him as part of the attack and with playmates Mbappe and Vinicius attracting markers and creating space, it could even increase.\n\nEngland international Bellingham could also play further back in central midfield, where he was typically deployed before arriving at Madrid. It would allow silky winger Rodrygo to join the attack on the right of a wider front three.\n\nAncelotti has helped Vinicius to develop from a promising but highly inconsistent winger into an elite forward who can break down any defence.\n\nThe Brazilian flexed his muscles by scoring a hat-trick against Barcelona in the Spanish Super Cup final in January, and netted in the Champions League final win over Dortmund.\n\nVinicius would also likely benefit with Mbappe beside him as opposition defences would no longer view him as the one key threat to be shackled by any means necessary.\n\n- Renewal -\n\nMbappe's arrival will also lay the next stone in a period of renewal for the club as a whole.\n\nPresident Florentino Perez lavished nearly 900 million euros ($970 million) on renovations to the Santiago Bernabeu stadium, which will finally finish in the summer.\n\nMadrid are also still pushing for a breakaway European Super League project but unlike ailing Barcelona, their partners-in-crime, they have the team to actually compete in one.\n\nThe club's veteran players are being phased out as new, hungry and extremely talented youngsters fill up the squad.\n\nWhile Barcelona have not found convincing replacements for departed greats Lionel Messi and Sergio Busquets, among others, Madrid have most of their homework done in advance.\n\nThe players who will take Luka Modric and the retiring Toni Kroos' places are already at the club.\n\nMadrid have Eduardo Camavinga, Federico Valverde and Aurelien Tchouameni in midfield, all 25 years old or under.\n\nHaving so many leading talents harks back to Madrid's Galactico era in the 2000s, except these stars have their best years ahead of them.\n\nBy contrast Luis Figo arrived at 27, David Beckham at 28 and Zinedine Zidane at 29.\n\nRodrygo, Brahim Diaz and Arda Guler are further youthful options up front for Ancelotti, with Madrid's squad the best in Spain.\n\nOne of the few doubts around Mbappe's arrival is about potential ego battles in the dressing room, and there is no better coach than the avuncular Italian to manage star names, as demonstrated during his two stints at the club.\n\nAnother is that both Vinicius and Mbappe prefer starting off the left, although this season the Brazilian has found his footing down the middle.\n\nIf he and Mbappe click as Madrid hope, their fluid movement and connection will make light of any positional concerns -- and any defence that crosses their path.", "source": {"uri": "today.rtl.lu", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTL Today"}, "authors": [], "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mbappe-vinicius-bellingham-form-madrids-175029067.html", "title": "Mbappe, Vinicius, Bellingham to form Madrid's dream attacking trio", "body": "Kylian Mbappe has finally signed for Real Madrid but fans must wait a few more weeks before a thrilling link-up with Vinicius Junior and Jude Bellingham becomes a reality.\n\nThe French forward will lead one of the most potent forward lines in world football after he arrives from Paris Saint-Germain at the end of his contract, a heady blend of skill, speed and dynamism.\n\nA lethal trio of such unequivocal quality brings to mind the new European and Spanish champions' glittering era with Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale and Karim Benzema causing havoc.\n\nThat vaunted 'BBC' trident inspired Madrid to multiple Champions League triumphs over the past decade, including three in a row between 2016 and 2018.\n\nMbappe idolised Ronaldo as a child and now has the chance to emulate the Portuguese forward, Madrid's all-time top goalscorer, in the Spanish capital.\n\nIn 2017 Mbappe turned down a potential move to Madrid from Monaco, in part because of the strength of the trio of attackers who seemed impossible to dislodge.\n\nNow Mbappe, who played alongside ageing former Barcelona attackers Lionel Messi and Neymar in Paris, will be the elder statesman at only 25.\n\nWorryingly for the rest of Europe, the trio are only improving, with Bellingham and Vinicius 20 and 23 years old respectively, leading Madrid to La Liga and Champions League glory this season.\n\nMbappe and Vinicius could lead the line with Bellingham supporting in an attacking midfield role.\n\nMadrid coach Carlo Ancelotti unlocked Bellingham's goalscoring prowess by deploying him as part of the attack and with playmates Mbappe and Vinicius attracting markers and creating space, it could even increase.\n\nEngland international Bellingham could also play further back in central midfield, where he was typically deployed before arriving at Madrid. It would allow silky winger Rodrygo to join the attack on the right of a wider front three.\n\nAncelotti has helped Vinicius to develop from a promising but highly inconsistent winger into an elite forward who can break down any defence.\n\nThe Brazilian flexed his muscles by scoring a hat-trick against Barcelona in the Spanish Super Cup final in January, and netted in the Champions League final win over Dortmund.\n\nVinicius would also likely benefit with Mbappe beside him as opposition defences would no longer view him as the one key threat to be shackled by any means necessary.\n\n- Renewal -\n\nMbappe's arrival will also lay the next stone in a period of renewal for the club as a whole.\n\nPresident Florentino Perez lavished nearly 900 million euros ($970 million) on renovations to the Santiago Bernabeu stadium, which will finally finish in the summer.\n\nMadrid are also still pushing for a breakaway European Super League project but unlike ailing Barcelona, their partners-in-crime, they have the team to actually compete in one.\n\nThe club's veteran players are being phased out as new, hungry and extremely talented youngsters fill up the squad.\n\nWhile Barcelona have not found convincing replacements for departed greats Lionel Messi and Sergio Busquets, among others, Madrid have most of their homework done in advance.\n\nHaving so many leading talents harks back to Madrid's Galactico era in the 2000s, except these stars have their best years ahead of them.\n\nBy contrast Luis Figo arrived at 27, David Beckham at 28 and Zinedine Zidane at 29.\n\nRodrygo, Brahim Diaz and Arda Guler are further youthful options up front for Ancelotti, with Madrid's squad the best in Spain.\n\nOne of the few doubts around Mbappe's arrival is about potential ego battles in the dressing room, and there is no better coach than the avuncular Italian to manage star names, as demonstrated during his two stints at the club.\n\nAnother is that both Vinicius and Mbappe prefer starting off the left, although this season the Brazilian has found his footing down the middle.\n\nIf he and Mbappe click as Madrid hope, their fluid movement and connection will make light of any positional concerns -- and any defence that crosses their path.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], That's what Real Madrid is.\"\n\nMbappe is expected to officially join Real Madrid this month.\n\nEndrick, meanwhile, had already signed for the Los Blancos and will join the squad this summer.", {"uri": "8159299605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "12:12:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T12:12:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T12:12:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/kylian-mbappe-makes-liverpool-arsenal-29284493", "title": "Mbappe makes Liverpool and Arsenal face issue only Real Madrid have answer to", "body": "Liverpool are busy planning for a new era without Jurgen Klopp. Before too long, they could be planning for one without Mohamed Salah, too.\n\nOver at Paris Saint-Germain, life without their superstar forward has already begun. Kylian Mbappe has confirmed he will leave the French capital club this summer and it is an open secret that he now will sign for Real Madrid on a free transfer after his contract expires.\n\nMbappe has been a long-term target for Madrid. But throughout the endless speculation about where the France World Cup winner's next destination would be, Liverpool have always been mentioned. The player, arguably the greatest of his generation, has gone on record himself to express his admiration for the Reds and their legendary outgoing manager.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool benefit from controversial TV decision as new figure proves dominance\n\nREAD MORE: Richard Hughes key to Liverpool triggering release clause and securing early summer transfer\n\nBut while the Premier League is the clear financial frontrunner in Europe when it comes to TV rights, transfer fees and wages, even the richest clubs among the English top flight, like Arsenal and Liverpool, had a job on their hands when it came to making the numbers add up for Mbappe, as Klopp conceded last year. While moving to Madrid for nothing in terms of a transfer fee, 'nothing' doesn't quite cover the extraordinary contract it would require to actually secure the 25-year-old's signature.\n\nDave Powell, the chief business of football writer for Reach Plc, explores the figures behind Mbappe's PSG contract, and why he was always going to be out of treach...\n\nCould Liverpool afford Kylian Mbappe?\n\nDave Powell: \"There isn't a major football club on the planet that won't have looked into the feasibility of signing Mbappe. Liverpool certainly did at one stage before quickly realising it was cost prohibitive. Numbers relating to Mbappe's salary have been doing the rounds for a long time, and weekly salaries ranging from \u00a31m-\u00a32m have been reported. The former is more likely to be the case, and a sum of around \u00a3650,000 is understood to be the truer figure.\n\n\"It has been through the sheer scale of his signing-on fee when he agreed to extend his deal with Paris Saint-Germain to 2025, a reported figure of \u00a3156m, that has been the real driver of potential wealth from the PSG deal, as well as loyalty bonuses that exist, and increase, with every year Mbappe remains a PSG player.\n\n\"The issue is that the PSG project is changing - it has had to - and the focus on reducing costs by bringing through more talent, like Warren Zaire-Emery, is paramount. That, allied with the diminution of media rights in France making the market as a competitive force even smaller, means that reaching his prime at 25, Mbappe feels he has done as much for French football domestically as he can. He has outgrown it. The Premier League is the biggest league in the world, and it isn't close. Its popularity is soaring overseas, and with markets like the US now ready to pay a premium for broadcast rights, its power will remain for some time.\n\n\"In theory, you would think if there is one place that Mbappe could land, aside from taking a deal from a Saudi Pro League side, it would be England. But while every 'big six' club would see the value from a competitive and marketing standpoint, the Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR) in the Premier League, and the fact that the clubs that would push the boat out are sailing close to those figures, make it a non-starter. Chelsea's willingness to spend \u00a31bn in the market has been widely covered, and that transfer spend has seen their amortisation costs jump significantly. So, too, has their wage bill, and to bring in a player of the calibre of Mbappe would be fanciful in the extreme.\n\n\"Arsenal, too, have been sailing close to the PSR limit, although that will be eased considerably when back-to-back Champions League seasons are accounted for. For Manchester United, they have also had to be mindful of PSR, but despite the struggle for success on the pitch, the club jumped back to fifth in the Deloitte Money League, with revenues of \u00a3648.5m. That is, however, some \u00a374.5m behind the world's biggest revenue-generating club, and the club where Mbappe is destined to land this summer, Real Madrid.\n\n\"English clubs usually operate a tighter wage structure. Offering players extraordinary amounts might seem wise in the short-term to land talent, but when it comes to renegotiations of contracts with existing players, they will likely try and get as close to parity as possible, and that can open the door to an enormously costly wage bill that can spiral out of control pretty quickly. English clubs know the limits of PSR, which is allowable losses of \u00a3105m over three years, with allowable deductions for investment into infrastructure, community, women's teams, and the academy, but there are enough grey areas to make it that clubs have to push the brakes if they can't trade players effectively to push up spending limits.\n\n\"In Spain it is different. LaLiga's economic controls are implemented by a group of analysts who review the finances of every club before establishing a squad cost limit. With this number, clubs go into the new transfer window knowing the total amount they can spend on first-team players and coaching staff. Those funds can be then be divided between transfer fees or wages in accordance with the club's preferences, as LaLiga does not impose a wage cap. Real Madrid, who have been building up to an Mbappe deal for a long time, have spent smarter with it in mind. They have held back on some major deals they may have pursued in order to land the player they have coveted for some time. They know exactly what they can spend, they know exactly how to make the numbers work.\n\n\"Clubs in the Premier League won't be engaging with a deal such as this with little planning and with the spectre of PSR or a potential move to UEFA's squad cost ratio to come. Deals like this aren't reactionary, and it's likely there won't be any Premier League club that has even tried their luck to convince Mbappe of a destination other than Spain for some time.\n\n\"How the deal is structured is another matter. A popular move in the US is a portion of wages being deferred and paid in significant tranches, as has been the recent case with the mammoth $700m (\u00a3557m) deal for Shohei Ohtani to play for the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team. That sum is to be paid in $2m-per-year sums for 10 years before deferred compensation arrives for another decade after that. North American sport is different, however, as there is more guarantee over long-term income, although there are few more guarantees in European football than Real Madrid being in the Champions League, with the club even still pushing for the creation of a European Super League.\n\n\"The numbers just don't add up for Liverpool and other Premier League clubs for Mbappe. No club has reigned in spending to try and land him, no team has played the long game like Real has. The die has been cast, and the enormous demands of Mbappe mean that he realistically has had only one option from the start, even if a transfer fee isn't involved.\"\n\nA version of this article was first published in February 2024.", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Liverpool Echo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dave_powell@liverpoolecho.co.uk", "name": "Dave Rodrygo has insisted that he will remain a Real Madrid player despite Kylian Mbappe's imminent arrival.\n\nFresh from winning their 15th Champions League trophy, Real Madrid are on the verge of unveiling Mbappe as their first signing of the summer transfer window.\n\nHaving been a long-term target for Real Madrid, Mbappe will finally join the Spanish giants won a free transfer upon the expiry of his Paris Saint-Germain contract.\n\nWith Mbappe set to join Carlo Ancelotti's side, there has been speculation as to whether his arrival could affect Rodrygo's future.\n\nThe Brazil international has been linked with a move to the Premier League amid interest from Liverpool and Manchester City.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nRodrygo addresses Real Madrid future\n\nEarlier this week, Rodrygo fuelled the rumours over his future when he refused to rule out a departure in an interview with DAZN.\n\nHowever, the 23-year-old later clarified his comments, taking to social media to state that his remarks were \"taken completely out of context\".\n\nRodrygo reaffirmed his commitment to Real Madrid following Saturday's 2-0 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League final at Wembley.\n\n\"Of course, I'm gonna stay at Real Madrid,\" Rodrygo told reporters. \"Why should I leave? I'm staying.\"\n\nRodrygo claimed his second Champions League winners' medal after goals from Dani Carvajal and Vinicius Junior proved enough to sink Dortmund.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nCan Rodrygo still prosper with Mbappe?\n\nThere are obvious concerns that Mbappe's signing will knock Rodrygo down the pecking order at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nThat could be the case if Ancelotti continues to implement a front two, but a change of formation could create the space to start Rodrygo, Mbappe and Vinicius.\n\nWhile he may not be on Mbappe's or Vinicius' level, Rodrygo remains a key player for Real Madrid as Ancelotti was keen to point out ahead of the Champions League final.\n\nThe forward made 51 competitive appearances throughout the 2023-24 campaign, scoring 17 goals and providing nine {"uri": "8158991869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "09:02:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T09:02:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T09:01:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/13146932/kylian-mbappe-to-real-madrid-where-does-forward-fit-in-carlo-ancelottis-star-studded-attack", "title": "Kylian Mbappe to Real Madrid: Where does forward fit in Carlo Ancelotti's star-studded attack?", "body": "Jude Bellingham slipped in Vinicius Jr to score and Real Madrid's key forward pair had done it. A Champions League trophy delivered without a recognised, world-class No 9 in the team.\n\nAll the talk before, during and after Saturday's win over Borussia Dortmund at Wembley surrounded how Carlo Ancelotti has masterminded another Real success having lost Karim Benzema last summer to Saudi Arabia. Now the talk is about how another French forward can take them to another level.\n\nKylian Mbappe is set to arrive at Real Madrid having snubbed the Spanish giants three times. Once after a trial with Real's U12 team, then twice to favour PSG in 2017 and 2022. Now he will arrive at the Bernabeu when his new side need him most.\n\n\"The only thing we're missing is that clinical nine,\" said Bellingham after Saturday's Champions League final.\n\n\"If he was to come and give us that, we would be in a really great place to go and take us to another level. One of the best players in the world!\"\n\nReal will now have their world-class No 9 - arguably one of the best out there. The problem is, what happens to players like Vinicius and Bellingham following their heroics not just at Wembley, but all through the season?\n\nAncelotti reacted to the loss of Benzema by not directly replacing him, instead adopting a 4-3-1-2 formation, using Vinicius and Rodrygo as 'split forwards' who adopt wide areas - allowing new signing Bellingham to venture in a free role behind them at the tip of a midfield diamond.\n\nIt is a front three that will not be broken up in terms of transfer sales. Vinicius and Bellingham - with 24 and 23 goals respectively this season - were the two most important players for Real this season. Rodrygo, despite rumours linking him with a move, has vowed to stay in the Spanish capital next season.\n\nBut Mbappe is now set to be the jewel in Real's shining crown, following his 256 goals in 308 games in the French capital. Yet how does PSG's old No 7 become Real Madrid's main man, and not take anything away from current Real No 7 Vinicius, who is arguably one of the best players in the world?\n\nAn issue could arise given Mbappe and Vinicius both played in the same position this season - and the Brazilian is not going to budge.\n\n\"Vinicius has really made the left-hand side his. That is his best position,\" Spanish football journalist Semra Hunter told Sky Sports News.\n\n\"Let's work under the premise that Ancelotti is going to stick with a 4-4-2 next season, with Jude Bellingham at the top of the midfield diamond.\n\n\"That means Vinicius and Mbappe can start in a two-pronged attack, like what Vinicius and Rodrygo have been doing this season.\"\n\nReplacing Rodrygo will not be an easy decision for Ancelotti, given the Brazilian forward's key role in Real's recent Champions League successes.\n\nThe Italian manager would be omitting the player who scored in both legs of this season's quarter-final victory over Manchester City, one that all but made the Champions League Real's to lose. And will Mbappe even accept Rodrygo's current role as 'right forward' to accommodate Vinicius?\n\nThere is the argument that Rodrygo barely plays on the right wing, despite being the 'right forward'. Two seasons ago, Ancelotti said the 23-year-old has \"so much potential as a centre forward or a second striker\", implying his role in Real's 4-3-1-2 is as central as it looks - making it perfect for Mbappe, who always preferred the No 9 role to a wide one at PSG.\n\nOr could all four - Mbappe, Vinicius, Rodrygo and Bellingham - play together in an ultra-attacking Ancelotti plan? He adopted a 4-3-3 formation at Real Madrid for years before Benzema's departure, so it would not be an alien move.\n\n\"Rodrygo is more tactically flexible - he can play on the right, left or as a No 10,\" added Hunter.\n\n\"He could play 4-3-3, with Mbappe in the middle and Vinicius and Rodrygo on the wings. But that means he would have to sacrifice a midfielder and they are so stacked in that area. I don't see that happening too often.\"\n\nMbappe is not the only new arrival at Real this summer, with Brazilian starlet Endrick also putting another dazzling option among the ranks. Given the 17-year-old's heroics to date for club and country, do not be surprised if he has something to say in this debate.\n\nBut the teenager will develop in his own time while the world watches Mbappe. He is the man Real Madrid are bringing in to dominate Europe.\n\nAnd if they are winning Champions League titles without him, what are the Spanish giants going to achieve with him?", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-377461255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "16:50:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T16:50:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T16:43:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/real-madrid-news-kylian-mbappe-kevin-durant-comparison-shot-down-by-fans-after-blockbuster-move", "title": "Kylian Mbappe-Kevin Durant comparison shot down by fans after blockbuster Real Madrid move", "body": "Kevin Durant's move to the Warriors is still way worse than Kylian Mbappe's decision to join Real Madrid, says fans.\n\nIt was only a matter of time before Kylian Mbappe's move to Real Madrid became official. Over the weekend, following Madrid's triumph in the UEFA Champions League Final over Borussia Dortmund, 2-0, Mbappe completed his blockbuster move. This epitomized the old adage of the rich getting richer, as the Los Blancos, winners of six of the past 11 CL trophies, have managed to add one of, if not the best attacking forward in football.\n\nAs is the case with nearly every bombshell move in sports, there are some who are not big fans. Some fans compared Mbappe's decision to join Real Madrid, the best club in European football this past season, to that of Kevin Durant's choice to spurn the Oklahoma City Thunder in free agency in 2016 to sign with the Golden State Warriors to form a superteam that made them an unbeatable unit, and arguably the best team ever assembled in NBA history.\n\nHowever, some fans contended that Kylian Mbappe's decision to join Real Madrid doesn't even come close to the impact Durant's choice to join the Warriors had on the sport's competitive picture.\n\n\"Not really a comparison, cause in football the best players always go to the best teams,\" Reddit user sergechewbacca wrote. Added user Pentinium, \"Lol, Mbappe is not even close go kd move.\"\n\nOne of the main differentiators is that Kevin Durant joined the team that eliminated him from championship contention. Meanwhile, it wasn't as if Kylian Mbappe's Paris Saint-Germain fell to Real Madrid in the Champions League. In fact, it was Madrid's opponent in the Champions League Final, Borussia Dortmund, that knocked off PSG.\n\n\"Mbappe's team, PSG, did not lose to Real Madrid this season. Also, he had been in the [discussion] of joining Real Madrid for a couple of years, and the [decision] had been already made before Real Madrid even [reached] the finals. So, KD way worse,\" Reddit user bandwagonguy83 explained.\n\nKevin Durant's Warriors move is way worse than Kylian Mbappe's Real Madrid decision, says fans\n\nBeyond the reasons mentioned above, the nature of football, or soccer, as a sport is that the impact of one player is far less than how much an individual can affect the game of basketball. In basketball, one player can do the heavy lifting by commandeering the majority of possessions. Meanwhile, in football, teams need every player to be a threat on the pitch -- a threat to pass, shoot, or make forward runs as well as defend.\n\nIn football, a player cannot simply dribble around the opposition. (Unless you're Lionel Messi.) There must be good synergy from all the 11 players on the pitch. Thus, adding Kylian Mbappe, while making Real Madrid an even more dangerous club, doesn't guarantee them the La Liga title or a successful defense of their Champions League trophy.\n\n\"There are 11 players on the field in football for a team There are only 5 in basketball. You tell me which sport can an individual be more impactful in,\" Reddit user idontknow_whatever wrote.\n\nMoreover, Kylian Mbappe has some experience when it comes to playing in stacked teams. It wasn't as if Paris Saint-Germain were slouches during his time with the club. In fact, at one point, PSG had Lionel Messi and Neymar play alongside Mbappe. Alas, despite dominating Ligue 1, PSG exited the Champions League in the Round of 16 during Messi's stint.\n\n\"At one point of time, psg team was Messi, Neymar and mbappe. Won s**t with it,\" user likpoper wrote.\n\nStill, it's important to note that Real Madrid will be an even scarier club to face next season. Their front line is as stacked as it can get, with Kylian Mbappe lining up alongside Vinicius Jr. and Rodrygo, with Jude Bellingham just right behind them waiting to make things happen. But this move is not as destructive to the parity of football as Kevin Durant's move to the Warriors was to the NBA.\n\nKD to the Dubs guaranteed championships\n\nIt's not like Kevin Durant simply made the decision to join the team that knocked them out of championship contention in 2016. He also joined a Warriors team that won 73 games the season prior, and he replaced Harrison Barnes, the forward who struggled mightily with his shot as the Dubs choked away a 3-1 series lead in the NBA Finals.\n\nDurant is an all-time great shooter in his own right, and adding him alongside Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson made for some ridiculously good but unfair basketball. He elevated an all-time great team and made them an unstoppable force. For two seasons, there was a sense of inevitability that the Warriors will be the team standing tall come season's end, and they might have won three championships in a row had Durant stayed healthy during the 2019 NBA playoffs.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jedd_pagaduan@clutchpoints.com", "name": "Jedd Pagaduan", {"uri": "8158751220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "06:17:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T06:17:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T06:16:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/06/03/kylian-mbappe-to-real-madrid-will-have-europe-quaking/", "title": "Kylian Mbappe to Real Madrid will have Europe quaking", "body": "Mbappe is joining Bellingham, Endrick, Guler, Camavinga, Vinicius and Rodrygo - players with their best years ahead of them\n\nReal Madrid will let the dust settle, the Cibeles Fountain - where they party with all their trophy wins - clear and the hangovers pass following their historic 15th Champions League triumph before they announce the signing of Kylian Mbappe.\n\nJust the construction of that sentence alone will send a shudder through the rest of European football. Without Mbappe, Madrid again proved to be the best team on the continent - and have won the Champions League six times in the past 11 years - and now they are going to add the world's most devastating forward. An announcement will be made this week.\n\nWhile it is the culmination of a pursuit that has effectively gone on for 12 years - ever since Mbappe was first invited to Madrid, with Zinedine Zidane acting as his chauffeur and Cristiano Ronaldo happy to be photographed - there was always an inevitability that he would one day pull on the fabled white shirt.\n\nThere may have been a few false starts and surprising U-turns but Mbappe is the world's most prized free transfer. His signing will prove to be far more important than Paris St-Germain acquiring Lionel Messi, given the captain of France is still just 25 and absolutely coming into his prime.\n\nThe lure of Madrid would always win just as it did for Jude Bellingham. His parents, Mark and Denise who guide his career, were smart enough to talk to all suitors - chiefly Manchester City - but, actually, always knew their son was destined to join Los Merengues.\n\nIt is not just Mbappe who is arriving this summer with Brazilian prodigy Endrick able to make the move after the Copa America and his 18th birthday in July. Madrid agreed a \u20ac60 million deal to sign him from Palmeiras 18 months ago and Endrick has already made his mark on the European stage, having scored the winning goal in Brazil's friendly victory over England last March.\n\nThe signing owed much to the extraordinarily assiduous work of Juni Calafat, Madrid's head scout whose influence extends way beyond that relatively modest title. The Brazilian has implemented the bold and successful policy of pursuing some of the world's most precocious talents and not least from his homeland.\n\nAnd so the rest of football will face a new dynasty; a new kindergarten version of the 'galacticos' and while Mbappe will immediately become the jewel in that line-up he will have to not only work hard to outshine the others but, at 25, is already one of the older players.\n\nThere is Bellingham at 20, Endrick at (soon-to-be) 18, Arda Guler 19, Eduardo Camavinga 21, Vinicius and Rodrygo both 23, Aurelien Tchouameni and Brahim Diaz both 24, and Fede Valverde at 25. These are players with their best years ahead of them but already - bar Endrick - Champions League winners.\n\nIn fact, more than half of Madrid's transfer spend over the last six years has been committed to players 21 or younger. That is around \u20ac415 million. But then Mbappe's market value would be \u20ac300 million alone as would Bellingham's. And that is without considering Vinicius.\n\nIt is a much more astute transfer policy than during Florentino Perez's first term as president, from 2000 to 2006, when he signed the likes of Zidane, Luis Figo and David Beckham and felt he needed to do so to stay in office. Perez is now 77 and not under that pressure. Neither are Madrid making the same misstep of overspending on someone like Eden Hazard. Now they wait, they sign young and they use their allure - hence why David Alaba and Antonio Rudiger were so eager to join on relatively cut-price deals.\n\nIt is also through expediency, of course, with Madrid's finances remaining under severe scrutiny, but no-one can argue that they have not - with their policy - added huge value to their squad and thrown down a challenge to their competitors. The appeal of the Madrid shirt is undoubted and with their latest signings they have not only brought more players with incredible potential and futures but strengthened what is already the most formidable club side in world football.\n\nWhat will be intriguing is how they fit in. The perceived wisdom is that Mbappe will have to play as a No 9 - a role he balked at with PSG and does not like for France either, preferring to come in from the left. But Vinicius should be retained there with Rodrygo on the right (for now).\n\nIt would mean Bellingham dropping into a midfield three alongside Valverde and either Tchouameni or Camavinga and it will be fascinating to see if it works. The worry for Madrid's rivals is that if any coach can do it then Carlo Ancelotti can and the Italian - called the \"final boss\" by Borussia Dortmund coach Edin Terzic before the Wembley final - extended his contract at the Bernabeu last December until 2026 having been interested in the Brazil national team job until there was a change of president.\n\nBut whatever happens, whatever permutation Ancelotti comes up with, Madrid will already be favourites to retain the Champions League when the final is played in Munich on May 31 2025. {"uri": "8159794870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "17:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T17:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T17:48:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.thisisanfield.com/2024/06/kylian-mbappe-did-hold-liverpool-transfer-talks-but-jurgen-klopp-says-thats-not-us/", "title": "Mbappe did hold LFC transfer talks - but Klopp says 'that's not us'", "body": "Kylian Mbappe has officially signed for Real Madrid following the expiry of his contract with Paris Saint-Germain, ending any more hopeful links with Liverpool.\n\nSince his emergence at Monaco, Mbappe has been regularly touted with a move to Anfield - and in fact, Liverpool explored a deal for the Frenchman on a number of occasions.\n\nIt became increasingly clear, however, that he was never set for Merseyside, with his new club the only realistic suitor.\n\nMbappe has signed a five-year deal with Real Madrid, joining the European champions as part of arguably the most complete squad of any club in many, many years.\n\nThough it is technically a free transfer, Mbappe is reported to have agreed a signing-on fee worth in the region of \u00a385 million, while his projected salary is around \u00a3650,000 a week.\n\nBy comparison, Liverpool's current highest earner is Mohamed Salah, on \u00a3350,000 per week.\n\nKlopp was not involved in Fenway Sports Group's talks with Mbappe on a private jet back in 2017, but the now-departed manager accepted the owners' stance on any deal.\n\nSpeaking at 'An Evening With Jurgen Klopp', the club's send-off event at the M&S Bank Arena in May, Klopp admitted signing players like Mbappe was \"not us.\"\n\n\"Can anybody mention that the city of Liverpool and LFC would be the club with endless money?\" he asked the 11,000 supporters in attendance.\n\n\"Spend what you want, Kylian Mbappe comes here, Bellingham comes here, Haaland comes here. That doesn't fit, that's not us. It is not us.\n\n\"That's how it is. Honestly, I have no problem with that.\n\n\"People can judge me for the finals I have lost, no problem at all, and there are some out there that do that.\n\n\"Or they judge me for the finals we won, that's fine as well. I couldn't care less, to be honest.\n\n\"We won what we won and we tried as hard as we could. But we did it the Liverpool way, that's how I see it.\n\n\"That means this city, where the city came from over the last decades, where the club came from maybe since the 90s where we didn't win anything anymore for a while, it's so impressive what we did together.\n\n\"And I mean together with our owners as well, because I know them, they're good people.\n\n\"It's not that they are not bothered about what we think, 'you always ask for money' and stuff like that.\"\n\nThere will be some fans who remain disappointed with a perceived lack of ambition from FSG when it comes to the transfer market.\n\nBut Mbappe's move sums up the situation for a club like Liverpool, fighting among the elite without the oil-funded, state-backed wealth that many of their closest rivals boast.\n\n\"We have owners who feel responsible for the club,\" Klopp continued.\n\n\"Are they the best in the world? I don't know the others, I cannot say that. But they work really hard as well so that we were successful.\n\n\"I felt supported. If other people say 'if he could have got supported more, he could have won more'. The Brazilian appeared to give both clubs a clear answer after the Champions League final.\n\nHis second European honor since joining the Bernabeu, having played a major role in both of those triumphs, it's initially hard to see why Rodrygo would be getting linked away at all. But the anticipated arrival of Kylian Mbappe will prompt some major competition for spots, with Wembley goal-scorer Vinicius Jr a pretty unmovable fixture on the wing.\n\nTo that end, in April, Liverpool supposedly 'contacted' Real Madrid about the player's availability. And right before the final, it was being claimed that Rodrygo himself was 'aware' of the interest, and in fact he made comments that appeared to leave the possibility of a move away from Real Madrid open.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool data wizards may have found cheaper Florian Wirtz but PSG and Spurs are there too\n\nREAD MORE: Aurelien Tchouameni offers gift to Liverpool fan after Champions League final\n\nAs for Manchester City, links have ratcheted up in intensity over the last couple of weeks. Marca claimed the winger was 'in the sights' of Pep Guardiola's team.\n\nYet in the afterglow of the final, per Give Me Sport, Rodrygo sent a clear message to his suitors. He appears determined to stay, even if it means battling with Mbappe for a spot.\n\n\"This week some media said about bids, clubs, interest... I don't know anything about it and I'm not interested,\" Rodrygo told reporters. \"Even if there are proposals, I have no idea about that... I'm staying. I'm happy here. How can I leave Real Madrid?\"\n\nThe BBC reported earlier today that Mbappe has now officially signed his Real Madrid contract, which means he will join as a free agent once his PSG deal expires on June 30. The move has been verbally agreed since February, with the groundwork stretching back years.\n\nLiverpool.com says: We've seen big trophy wins influence transfer decisions in the past. Would Steven Gerrard have stayed in 2005 without Istanbul?\n\nIn any case, even if Rodrygo had been on the move, Liverpool rarely signs players directly from European giants. Manchester City might have been a more likely destination, so on balance it's probably no bad thing that he intends to stay.\n\nThen again, with the Mbappe situation, it's worth Liverpool keeping a watchful eye on how things pan out. The France captain has been heavily linked with Real for some time but there have always been rumors about a potential move to Liverpool.\n\nMbappe has shot to superstardom in Paris but his career could have panned out very differently. He actually met with Liverpool back in 2017 when he was a teenager at Monaco to discuss a possible switch.\n\nThere were further talks two years ago and Mbappe revealed all to the Daily Telegraph, saying: \"I talked to Liverpool because it's the favorite club of my mum, my mum loves Liverpool. I don't know why, you will have to ask her. It's a good club and we met them five years ago. When I was in Monaco I met them. It's a big club.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool urged to make shock $51m Everton transfer for ace Jurgen Klopp raved about\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool transfer target 'wants to leave' as Jamie Carragher tips Champions League bid\n\nJurgen Klopp was eager to sound caution after links re-emerged to Liverpool last year, when it became apparent he would be leaving PSG. I wouldn't like to ruin the story now... but as far as I know, there's nothing to it.\n\n\"It's possible that someone else from the club is preparing something and wants to surprise me... that hasn't happened in the eight years that I've been here. That would be the first time.\"\n\nLiverpool's FSG owners have justifiably been reluctant to spend record sums of money over the years and in his farewell event with supporters last week, Klopp again referenced the French superstar.\n\n\"If Liverpool would be the club with endless money, you can spend what you want,\" the 56-year-old said. \"Kylian Mbappe comes here, Bellingham comes here, Haaland comes here. It doesn't fit, it's not us. It is not us. That's how it is.\"\n\nLiverpool.com says: Liverpool moving for Mbappe was always going to be unlikely once he made the move to PSG, although it says a lot for the regard in which the Reds were held that he continued to be linked with a move to Anfield. Eugenie le Sommer has a record 93 for the women's team.\n\nMbappe scored an unforgettable hat-trick in the 2022 World Cup final, finishing as the tournament Golden Boot winner with eight goals even as his then PSG club-mate Lionel Messi inspired Argentina to the title on penalties.\n\nHe is also one of only six players to score four or more goals in a game for France, against Kazakhstan in November 2021.\n\nHe has scored 12 goals in World Cups and six in qualifiers, another dozen in European Championship qualifiers, seven in the Nations League and nine in friendlies.\n\nHe goes to Euro 2024 looking for his first goals in the finals of the competition, having drawn a blank in four appearances in 2021 and missed the decisive penalty in a shoot-out defeat to Switzerland.\n\nVinicius Jr was Real Madrid's top scorer in the season just concluded, netting in the Champions League final to edge out Jude Bellingham 24 goals to 23.\n\nThat is the lowest tally for Real's leading marksman since before the signing of Cristiano Ronaldo in 2009, with the Portuguese averaging 50 goals a season in all competitions in his nine years with the club including 61 in 2014-15 and 60 in 2011-12.\n\nKarim Benzema then took over the mantle, with at least 30 goals in four of the next five seasons - peaking with 44 in 2021-22 when he scored 15 in the Champions League alone.\n\nHis fellow Frenchman Mbappe will arrive with expectations to lead the line in the same way as those players once did.\n\nStill only 25 and having scored 42, 39, 41 and then 44 club goals in all competitions over the last four that could start dynasty", "body": "Real Madrid are the deserved champions of Europe, but they could get even better next season.\n\nLos Blancos announced the sensational signing of Kylian Mbappe on Monday as he departs Paris Saint-Germain.\n\nThe forward, a World Cup winner with France and seven-time Ligue 1 champion, is regarded as one of the best players in world football even though he's never won the Champions League.\n\nHe joins the reigning champions' squad that boasts some of the best talent in Europe, including Jude Bellingham and Vinicius Jr.\n\nWith Madrid's new blockbuster signing made official soon, talkSPORT.com has looked at how they could line up next season.\n\nThibaut Courtois, a three-time LaLiga winner, is likely to return as the starting goalkeeper having missed most of the 2023/24 campaign through an ACL injury.\n\nHe started in the Champions League final over Andriy Lunin and Kepa Arrizabalaga, with the latter set to return to Chelsea this summer at the end of his loan spell.\n\nAt centre-back, both Eder Militao and David Alaba also suffered ACL injuries this season, with the former returning in March and the latter not playing since December.\n\nMilitao, who has won ten trophies in five years at Madrid, could therefore claim a starting spot alongside Antonio Rudiger, the former Chelsea man who kept 22 clean sheets this season.\n\nFerland Mendy has regularly been named as their left-back since he joined from Lyon in 2019, contributing to much of their domestic and European success.\n\nHaving scored the opener in their Champions League final win over Borussia Dortmund, the long-serving Dani Carvajal is set to remain at right-back.\n\nThe Spaniard has been at Madrid since 2013 and has made 416 appearances for the club, winning four LaLiga titles and six European crowns amongst other honours.\n\nAlthough Toni Kroos recently announced his retirement Madrid still have plenty of midfield options, with Federico Valverde missing just one game this season.\n\nHe could be poised to play alongside the talented 21-year-old Frenchman Eduardo Camavinga, with club legend and veteran Luka Modric and Aurelien Tchouameni also worthy options.\n\nAttacking midfielder Bellingham is highly likely to play in front of them off the back of an incredible debut season.\n\nThe England star scored 23 goals and assisted a further 13 across all competitions in their treble-winning campaign, in which he made 42 appearances.\n\nOn the left of Madrid's front three could be Vinicius Jr, who scored their second goal in the Champions League final.\n\nIt took his tally to 24 for the season and like Bellingham, the Brazilian has been touted as a contender for this year's illustrious Ballon d'Or award.\n\nThe versatile Rodrygo has proven an effective teammate alongside his countryman in the attack and he looks set to shift into his popular position out on the right wing.\n\nAnd leading the line for Madrid is set to be Mbappe, with the 25-year-old arriving as their latest 'Galactico' signing.\n\nHaving scored 256 goals in 308 appearances for PSG, the Frenchman is one of the most clinical finishers in world football and could be an ideal role model for 17-year-old Endrick, who also arrives this summer.\n\nMbappe will surely take the team to the next level and feature in a side that could dominate Europe for the years to come.\n\nSpeaking to talkSPORT, European football expert Andy Brassell echoed this sentiment: \"It does just give us that feeling that maybe this is the point where Real Madrid start to build a dynasty in Europe.\n\n\"They've got a team that was kind of in semi-transition this season, where Bellingham has had a much better season than anyone could have reasonably expected.\n\n\"A lot of their other players have done likewise but in this, in inverted commas 'transition season', they've won LaLiga by losing one game all season, they've won the Champions League and they've won the [Spanish] Super Cup, it's extraordinary.\n\n\"So you do think with him and Endrick arriving from Brazil of course, they're in an incredible position of strength.\"", "source": {"uri": "8159834414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "18:21:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T18:21:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T18:21:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.espn.com/soccer/insider/story/_/id/40257086/what-mbappe-transfer-real-madrid-means-psg-europe-competition", "title": "Kylian Mbappe has joined Real Madrid -- now what? Can anyone else even compete?", "body": "Ryan O'Hanlon is a staff writer for ESPN.com. He's also the author of \"Net Gains: Inside the Beautiful Game's Analytics Revolution.\"\n\nWe probably still shouldn't believe it until we see him attempting to juggle a commemorative soccer ball in front of the media and fans at the Santiago Bernabeu, but it seems like it finally happened. Kylian Mbapp\u00e9 has signed with Real Madrid, the club announced on Monday.\n\nThus ends nearly a half-decade of coy will-he-won't-he between Mbappe, Real Madrid president Florentino Perez, a succession of Paris Saint-Germain managers, every French player on Real Madrid, PSG president Nasser Al-Khelaifi, and even the French prime minister, Emmanuel Macron.\n\nWhile it's normal to feel worn down by this saga -- as well as a resignation at the inevitability of Real Madrid signing the best soccer player in the world -- this is still quite rare. The best soccer player in the world rarely changes teams because whatever team is employing the best soccer player in the world (A) wants to keep said player, and (B) likely has enough money to continue employing said player.\n\nThe last time the best player in the world changed teams was maybe Lionel Messi, who moved from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain in the summer of 2021, thanks to Barca's incredible financial incompetence. But Messi was already 34 years old at that point. The last time the best player in the world changed teams in his prime arguably was when Cristiano Ronaldo went from Manchester United to Real Madrid in 2009, or more likely when the Brazilian Ronaldo changed from Inter Milan to Real Madrid in 2002.\n\nSensing a theme here? On the rare occasion a young, established, worldwide superstar switches teams, he tends to join Real Madrid. Eugenie le Sommer has a record 93 for the women's team.\n\nMbappe scored an unforgettable hat-trick in the 2022 World Cup final, finishing as the tournament Golden Boot winner with eight goals even as his then PSG club-mate Lionel Messi inspired Argentina to the title on penalties.\n\nHe has scored 12 goals in World Cups and six in qualifiers, another dozen in European Championship qualifiers, seven in the Nations League and nine in friendlies.\n\nHe goes to Euro 2024 looking for his first goals in the finals of the competition, having drawn a blank in four appearances in 2021 and missed the decisive penalty in a shoot-out defeat to Switzerland.\n\nThat is the lowest tally for Real's leading marksman since before the signing of Cristiano Ronaldo in 2009, with the Portuguese averaging 50 goals a season in all competitions in his nine years with the club including 61 in 2014-15 and 60 in 2011-12.\n\nKarim Benzema then took over the mantle, with at least 30 goals in four of the next {"uri": "8159870410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "18:53:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T18:53:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T18:52:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/sports/2024/6/3/real-madrid-sign-frances-kylian-mbappe-on-free-transfer-after-psg-exit", "title": "'Dream come true': Kylian Mbappe signs five-year deal with Real Madrid", "body": "Mbappe joins the Spanish and European champions as a free agent a month after terminating his contract with PSG.\n\nFrance forward Kylian Mbappe has joined Real Madrid as a free agent on a five-year contract, the LaLiga club has announced, ending a transfer saga that rumbled on for years.\n\nThe signing was confirmed via a social media statement from Real Madrid on Monday.\n\n\"Real Madrid C F and Kylian Mbappe have reached an agreement whereby he will be a Real Madrid player for the next five seasons,\" the Spanish and European champions.\n\nMbappe shared images of himself as a youngster in a Real Madrid kit as well as meeting Cristiano Ronaldo onto his social media profiles shortly after the club statement.\n\n\"A dream come true,\" he wrote. \"So happy and proud to join the club of my dream @realmadrid.\n\n\"Nobody can understand how excited I am right now. Can't wait to see you, Madridistas, and thanks for your unbelievable support. Hala Madrid!\"\n\nThe 25-year-old captain of the French national team had announced he was leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in a video posted on social media platform X on May 10.\n\nMbappe will move to Real Madrid in July after his PSG contract expires on June 30, but the forward will be unveiled before joining up with the France squad for the European Championship in Germany.\n\nMbappe joins a star-studded side in Madrid with the likes of Ballon d'Or favourites Vinicius Jr and Jude Bellingham, led by Italian Carlo Ancelotti - the most successful coach in Champions League history, with five titles.\n\nAlthough Mbappe won several trophies at PSG, often completing domestic doubles and trebles, the Champions League has eluded him and remains the only major honour left to complete his sparkling resume.\n\nMbappe leaves PSG after seven years at the club where he won six Ligue 1 titles and four French Cups, finishing his career in the capital city as the club's all-time top scorer with 256 goals.\n\nThe 2018 World Cup winner surprised PSG last year when he sent a letter stating he would not take up the option of a one-year extension when his contract expires in June.\n\nThe letter led to a standoff with the club and Mbappe was omitted from the first-team squad before being reinstated.\n\nAllowing Mbappe to run down the final year of his contract meant PSG were unable to recoup any of the 180 million euro ($196m) transfer fee they paid in 2017 to sign him from AS Monaco.\n\nWhen the transfer was completed, Mbappe became the second-most expensive player of all time after his former PSG team-mate Neymar.\n\nReal Madrid had courted Mbappe in the past but failed to land the player, who signed a contract extension with PSG in May 2022 when the Spanish club had a bid rejected.\n\nWith Mbappe finally in their ranks, the club can look at consolidating their dominance in LaLiga, where they lost only once last season to win the title by 10 points and they were
